To Set Up Automatic File Synchronization You can use automation schedules to perform periodic synchronization between a file on an Acumatica ERP site and a file on a local computer or network. You find the file whose synchronization you want to schedule by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202520|SM202520]) Search in Files (SM202520) form, configure file synchronization by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance (SM202510) form, and then schedule the synchronization on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202530|SM202530]) File Synchronization (SM202530) form. Before You Proceed Before you start configuring synchronization between a file on your Acumatica ERP website and a file or folder on your local network, share the folder (which includes the file to be synchronized or which will itself be synchronized with the file on the Acumatica ERP website) through your operating system. Make sure the folder is shared with proper rights for writing. Synchronization (of the export type) with a folder means that each time synchronization is performed, a new file with the appropriate date and time stamp is created in the specified folder. To Configure File Synchronization Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202520|SM202520]) Search in Files (SM202520) form. To find the file, on the form, do one of the following: In the Selection area, specify criteria to help you find the file. This criteria can include the file name (or part of the file name), the time interval of the import, and the name of the user who imported the file or checked it out. The table in the right pane lists the files that match the criteria you specified. In the left pane, navigate to and select the form to which the file is attached. The table in the right pane lists the files attached to the entities created by using the form you selected in the left pane. In the right pane, click the file to open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form for this file and view file properties. On the Synchronization tab, select the Synchronize check box. In the Synchronization Type box, select Shared Folder . In the Path box, enter the path to the shared folder on a local network computer. In the Login and Password boxes, type the login and password of an account with sufficient rights to allow system access to the shared folder. If you synchronize files with an FTP server, you should use a login without the /, or \ characters in synchronization settings. Otherwise, Acumatica ERP will not be able to connect to the server. To configure synchronization with the folder, do the following: Select the Synchronize Folder Content check box. In the Import File Validation Mask box, enter a validation mask for the files in the folder that are involved in synchronization. On the form toolbar, click Save . To Schedule File Synchronization After you have configured the file synchronization, you can perform synchronization manually by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202530|SM202530]) File Synchronization form. Alternatively, you can assign it to a schedule to be performed automatically by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM205020|SM205020]) Automation Schedules (SM205020) form. For more information about automation schedules, see Scheduled Processing. To schedule file synchronization, do the following: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202530|SM202530]) File Synchronization (SM202530) form. In the Operation box, select the synchronization operation to be performed, Import File or Export File . This displays (in the table in the lower part of the form) the pairs of files for which synchronization of the selected type has been configured. In the Selected column, select the check boxes for the files you want to have automatically updated. On the form toolbar, click Schedules Add . This opens the ([~/?ScreenId=SM205020|SM205020]) Automation Schedules (SM205020) form as a pop-up. On the ([~/?ScreenId=SM205020|SM205020]) Automation Schedules form, in the Description box, enter a description of the new schedule. On the Details tab, specify the additional settings of the schedule: Optional: In the Starts On box of the Details tab, select the start date. By default, the schedule execution starts on the current business date. Optional: If you need to specify an expiration date for the schedule, clear the No Expiration Date check box, and specify the expiration date in the Expires On box. Do one of the following: If you want to limit the number of executions, in the Execution Limit box, specify the number of times the schedule should be executed. If you do not need to limit the number of executions, select the No Execution Limit check box. Optional: In the Process with Branch box, select the branch under which the schedule should be processed. For example, if documents are created by this schedule, the system creates these documents and specifies the selected branch for each document. Optional: Change the time zone in which the schedule will operate. By default, the time zone specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM203010|SM203010]) User Profile (SM203010) form for the currently signed-in user is selected. On the Schedule tab, configure the execution dates and time as follows: Specify how often the schedule execution should be performed: To execute the schedule daily or every x days, do the following: In the Schedule Type section, select Daily . Optional: In the Schedule Details section, in the Next Execution Date box, select the date when the schedule should be executed next. In the Every x Day(s) box, type the number of days between successive executions of the schedule. To execute the schedule weekly or every x weeks, do the following: In the Schedule Type section, select Weekly . Optional: In the Schedule Details section, in the Next Execution Date box, select the date when the schedule should be executed next. In the Every x Week(s) box, type the number of weeks between successive executions of the schedule. Select the appropriate check boxes for the day or days of the week on which the schedule should be executed. To execute the schedule monthly or every x months, do the following: In the Schedule Type section, select Monthly . Optional: In the Schedule Details section, in the Next Execution Date box, select the date when the schedule should be executed next. In the Every x Month(s) box, type the number of months between successive executions of the schedule. Select when the schedule should be executed: the day of the month, or the week in the month and the day of the week (such as the third Friday of the month). To execute the schedule once per financial period or every x financial periods, perform the following steps: In the Schedule Type section, select By Financial Period . Optional: In the Schedule Details section, in the Next Execution Date box, select the date when the schedule should be executed next. In the Every x Period(s) box, type the number of financial periods between successive executions of the schedule. Select the appropriate option button to indicate when the schedules should be executed: at the end of the period, at the start of the period, or on a fixed day of the period (which you should specify if you select this option button). In the Execution Time section, specify the particular time of the day to start and stop the processing as follows: In the Starts On box, select the hour and minute when the first execution of the schedule should start. If you want the processing to be stopped at specific time or you want the processing to be repeated multiple times a day, in the Stops On box, select the hour and minute when the first execution of the schedule should stop. If execution of the schedule should be repeated multiple times a day, in the Every box, select the interval between successive executions of the schedule. In the Next Execution Time box, make sure the next execution time is correct. If you want the system to execute the schedule at exactly the time specified in the Next Execution Time box, select the Exact Time check box. If the check box is cleared, the system may shift the next execution time of the schedule by multiple minutes. On the Conditions tab, specify conditions to select only specific pairs of files for automatic synchronization: In the Field Name box, select Name . In the Condition box, select Equals . In the Value box, select the file by its name. On the Filter Values tab, choose the synchronization operation to be performed, Import File or Export File . Click Save on the form toolbar to create the schedule. When you save a newly created schedule, the system gives it an identifier in accordance with the built-in numbering sequence intended for automation schedules. To View the History of Schedule Application On the Configuration tab, click Document Management . In the left pane, click Schedule File Synchronization . On the form toolbar, click Schedules History . In the dialog box that opens, select the schedule whose history you want to view, and specify the date range for which you want to view the history. Click History to view the history of the schedule execution and the list of file pairs that were synchronized automatically as the result of the schedule application. To Manage Files In Acumatica ERP, you can import a file into the system and attach it to ERP records or documents (such as stock items or bills), record details, notification templates, and wiki articles. You can also manage these files in a variety of ways, as this article describes. To Open a File for Maintenance If the file is attached to a record or document created by using an Acumatica ERP form: Open the form, and then select the record or document the file is attached to. On the form title bar, click Files . In the Files dialog box, click Edit to the right of the file name. If the file is attached to a record detail: Open the form, and then select the record or document that has the detail row to which the file is attached. In the table, at the beginning of the detail row the file is attached to, click the File Attached icon. In the Files dialog box, click Edit to the right of the file name. If the file is attached to an article (as with an inserted image in the article): Open the article that has the file attached. Point to the image and click the Edit link that appears next to the image. Clicking Edit opens the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance (SM202510) form, which displays the details of the file attachment. From this form, you can manage the file in a variety of ways. To Find a File To find a file by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SE000040|SE000040]) Search Form (SE000040): In the navigation pane, in the Search box, type the file name or part of it. Click Search . On the Search form, in the Scope box, select Files . In the Results list, click the file name. This opens the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, which displays the details of the file attachment. To find a file by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202520|SM202520]) Search in Files (SM202520) form: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202520|SM202520]) Search in Files form. Optional: To view the files that match particular criteria, in the Selection area, specify the criteria and press Enter. Optional: To view the files attached to documents created by the form, select the form in the left pane. In the right pane, click the file name. This opens the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, which displays the details of the file attachment. To find an unattached file: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202520|SM202520]) Search in Files form. In the left pane, click Unassigned . Optional: To view the files that match particular criteria, in the Selection area, specify the search criteria and press Enter. In the right pane, click the file name. This opens the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, which displays the details of the file attachment. To Update a File Open the file for maintenance. Optional: In the form toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, click Check Out to make the file unavailable to other users for editing while you are updating it. Optional: On the Versions tab, select the file version you want to edit and click Get Selected Version on the table toolbar to download the selected file version for editing. Make needed edits to the file and save the edited version to your computer. On the form toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, click Upload New Version to open the File Upload dialog box and import the edited version of the file into the system. If you checked the file out, select the Check In check box to make the file available for editing to other users. To View File Versions Open the file for maintenance. On the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, do the following: In the Summary area, view whether the file is checked out and, if so, by whom. On the Versions tab, view the list of file versions, along with information about who saved each version and when. On the Versions tab, select a version and then click View Selected Version to view the file version. To See Which Entities or Wiki Articles a File Is Attached To Open the file for maintenance. On the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, do the following: On the Articles tab, view the list of the wiki articles the file is attached to. On the Entities tab, view the list of the entities the file is attached to. To Get a Link to a File You can copy a link to a file that has been imported into the system. You can then send the link to another user or insert the link into a wiki article. Open the file for maintenance. In the Summary area of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, copy the link you want to use. To Configure Access to a File To define the primary document for the file (the document from which roles inherit access rights to it), do the following: Open the file for maintenance. On the Access Rights tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, in the Primary Screen box, select the primary form. In the Access Rights table, make needed changes to the access rights. On the form toolbar, click Save to save the changes. To define the primary wiki article for the file (the article from which roles inherit access rights to it), do the following: Open the file for maintenance. On the Access Rights tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, in the Wiki box, select the wiki. In the Primary Page box, select the primary article. You can check the access rights of the roles in the Access Rights table. On the form toolbar, click Save to save the changes. To make the file available to all users, do the following: Open the file for maintenance. On the Access Rights tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, select the Is Public check box. On the form toolbar, click Save to save the changes. To make the file unavailable to users accessing the system from outside, such as through file transfer protocol (FTP), do the following: Open the file for maintenance. On the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, in the Summary area, select the Is Hidden check box. On the form toolbar, click Save to save the changes. To Delete a Version of a File Open the file for maintenance. On the Versions tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, select the file version and click Delete Row in the table toolbar. To Delete a File Deleted files cannot be restored. Open the file for maintenance. On the form toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance form, click Delete . Click OK to delete the file permanently.

Monitoring system performance insures that the system is running optimally and users do not experience any problems with doing their jobs.{br}
In this chapter, you will find information on Acumatica ERP functionality that helps you with monitoring system health.
row.PlainText: Monitoring System Health Monitoring system performance insures that the system is running optimally and users do not experience any problems with doing their jobs. In this chapter, you will find information on Acumatica ERP functionality that helps you with monitoring system health.

row.column: System Health: General Info You use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201530|SM201530]) System Monitor (SM201530) form for reporting current application operational data and statistics, as well as for reporting any potential or existing performance issues. If Acumatica ERP is used in the premises of your company or in your own data center you can correlate the environment limitations in which the system is operating in relationship to the data that is reporting on this form. Learning Objectives In this chapter, you will learn how to do the following: Monitor currently running processes, discover and analyze the threads that are currently frozen or no longer responding. Review active user list Track memory and CPU utilization Analyze log of system events Monitoring statuses of push notifications and business event queues Using the Request Profiler tool Applicable Scenarios You monitor system health in the following cases: You are a system administrator and monitoring system health is a part of your routine. Users of the system reported that the site performance slowed down. Users of the system reported that some tasks were failed to complete. For example, scheduled operations failed or at least one record has not been processed successfully. Monitoring Running Processes On the Running Processes tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201530|SM201530]) System Monitor (SM201530) form, you can monitor all batch processing operations that are currently being performed in the system, such as the release of multiple transactions at once, preparation of dunning letters, generation of a report, creation of a tenant snapshot, or use of an import or export scenario. Your server may be slow because of a large number of such operations running simultaneously. By default, the table displays only the processes of the current user. To view the processes run by all users, you select the Show All Users check box on the tab toolbar. You can navigate to a form where a user launched a process by selecting the process in the table and clicking View Screen on the table toolbar. The system navigates you to the form where you can stop the operation or review occurred errors, if any. For details, on mass processing, see Processing Pop-Up Window. You can abort any running process by selecting a process in the list and clicking Abort on the table toolbar. For long operations Acumatica ERP runs threads. You can discover and analyze the threads that are currently frozen or no longer responding by clicking Active Threads on the table toolbar and view details in the pop-up panel. If there is at least one active thread, the panel contains information about currently running threads. Reviewing List of Active User You use the Active Users tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201530|SM201530]) System Monitor (SM201530) form to review the list of currently active users. You can filter users by the way a user accessed the system, which can be one of the following: User Interface : A user signed in by using their username and password either on the Acumatica ERP Sign-In page, or through the mobile application, or through single sign-on page provided that SSO with Google or Microsoft Account has been set up. API : A user is a client application that signed in by using the method for singing in of the contract-based SOAP API, contract-based REST API, or screen-based SOAP API, or by using OAuth 2.0 mechanism of authorization for applications. You can select a user in the list, click View User on the table toolbar and the system navigates you to the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users (SM201010) form, displaying information about the currently selected user. Tracking Resource Usage You use the Resource Usage tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201530|SM201530]) System Monitor (SM201530) form to monitor how an Acumatica ERP instance is using memory and CPU of application server where the instance is installed. At the bottom of the form you can view charts that illustrate current CPU and memory usage of application server by the Acumatica ERP instance. You can switch off the Java script that performs automatic update of the charts by modifying value for the EnableResourceUsageAutoUpdate key in the web.config file. Analyzing System Event Log You use the System Events tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201530|SM201530]) System Monitor (SM201530) form to analyze log of system events. The tab lists log records for multiple system events. You can explore the log for errors, warnings, or operations that consume excessive resources. For details, see System Health: System Event Log. Monitoring System Queues You use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM302010|SM302010]) System Queues Monitor (SM302010) form to monitor statuses of push notifications and business event queues. By using this form, you can clear queues and restart dispatchers both for push notification and business events. In a cluster environment you should access this form by node. Using Request Profiler The Request Profiler is an embedded tool you can use to troubleshoot performance-related issues in Acumatica ERP or an Acumatica Framework-based application. For details, see System Health: Request Profiler.

System Health: System Event Log By using the elements in the Selection area of the System Events tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201530|SM201530]) System Monitor (SM201530) form, you can narrow the list of events by the sources of the event, the severity level of the event, and the date range. To view the details of an event, you select the event in the table and the system displays these details in the bottom pane of the form. Event Sources On the System Events tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201530|SM201530]) System Monitor (SM201530) form, the system logs events triggered by the following sources: Customization License Push notifications Resource governor Scheduler System By using the Source multi-select drop-down box in the Selection area of the tab, you may narrow the list of events by selecting one source or multiple sources. By default, the All option is selected. Event Severity Levels You can use the Level drop-down box in the Selection area of the System Events tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201530|SM201530]) System Monitor (SM201530) form to narrow the list of events by severity level. When you select any severity level, the system narrows the list to only events with the selected level and higher (that is, more severe) severity levels. The box contains the following options, which are listed from the least to most severe: Information (default): Events of all levels are shown in the table; this is the least severe level. Warning : The table displays events with the selected severity and with the higher levels, which are Error and Fatal . Error : Events of only the Error and Fatal levels are listed in the table. Fatal : The table shows only events with the Fatal level. Logged System Events In the table below you can find the list of the events that are logged by the system. Logged System Events Source Severity Level Event Business Events Warning Business event queue dispatcher has been restarted Processing of a business event took longer than expected Error Business event queue dispatcher failed Business event queue has issues Processing of a business event has failed Customization Information A customization project has been published A customization project has been unpublished Error Publishing of a customization project failed with an error License Information License has been activated License has been deleted Warning Sign-In limit exceeded An API request has been throttled Push Notifications Warning Push notification queue dispatcher has been restarted Processing of a push notification took longer than expected Error Push notification queue dispatcher failed Push notification queue has issues Sending of push notification has failed Processing of a push notification has failed ResourceGovernor Warning Memory working set exceed threshold Error A request has been terminated An API request has been terminated Scheduler Information Automation Scheduler has been initialized Warning Automation Scheduler has been aborted At least one record has not been processed successfully Automation Schedule scenario has not been performed due to the database lockout Error Automation Scheduler has failed with an exception System Information The site has started The site is shutting down Site upgrade has started Site upgrade has been applied successfully Database upgrade has started Database upgrade has been applied successfully New tenant has been created A snapshot has been successfully restored A snapshot has been created A tenant copy has been created Time-consuming task has finished Warning Database upgrade completed with errors Time-consuming task has started Error Site upgrade failed with exception Database upgrade failed with exception Snapshot restoration failed Failed to create a snapshot Creating of a tenant copy has failed Storage of Event Logs Logged event details are stored in database. All events older that 30 days are removed from the database. The built-in removal process launches automatically every day and when a website is restarted. You can change the default frequency by modifying value for the SystemEventDBSink:CleansingPeriod key in the web.config file. The value should be set in the TimeSpan format, for example, 0.1:0:0 stands for cleaning database every hour.

System Health: Request Profiler The ([~/?ScreenId=SM205070|SM205070]) Request Profiler (SM205070) is an embedded tool you can use to troubleshoot performance-related issues in Acumatica ERP or an Acumatica Framework-based application. Using the Request Profiler You use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM205070|SM205070]) Request Profiler: To monitor the time and memory needed for any URL request performed in Acumatica ERP. To analyze the time needed for any SQL request of selected URL request. To obtain information about exceptions that have occurred in the Acumatica ERP instance, and to view its traces. To monitor all URL requests in Acumatica ERP, in the Profiler Options section, select the Log Requests check box. To monitor only the long URL requests that need more than 1000 milliseconds to run, enter 1000 in the Svr Time Threshold box of the Filters section. To monitor URL requests with 500 or more SQL requests, enter 500 in the SQL Count Threshold box of the Filters section. To obtain information about SQL requests within URL requests, you select the Log SQL check box in the Profiler Options section. You use the SQL Profiler Pop-up Panel to view the information. We recommend that you activate the Log SQL mode for only a limited period because it can degrade system performance. To obtain information about application exceptions within URL requests, you select the Log Trace Messages and Log Exceptions check boxes in the Profiler Options section. You use the Trace Profiler Pop-up Panel to view the information. Working in Cluster Mode The Request Profiler works in cluster mode. When you run the profiler on a cluster, it launches on all nodes of the cluster. The profiler settings apply to each cluster node. To specify the identifier of the cluster node, you can use one of the following approaches: In the appSettings tag of the web.config file, specify a string value for the ClusterNodeId attribute, such as the following. <add key="ClusterNodeId" value="MyClusterNodeName" /> Create the ...\App_Data\WebsiteHeaders.txt file that contains the identifier. Do not specify the identifier; the system will automatically create a GUID for the cluster node. If you need to identify a cluster node for the URL request on the Request Profiler form, use the Headers column of the log table. In cluster mode, the column contains the GUID or the identifier of the cluster node.

row.Content: Within Acumatica ERP, users can search wikis and various system entities, thus making the process of looking up for data quick and easy. This chapter describes the main points in search configuration and management. ==In This Chapter==[anchor|#ul_kp2_rqh_5r] *[HelpRoot_Administration\SM__con_Search_Options|Search in Acumatica ERP] *[HelpRoot_Administration\SM__how_Search_indexes_update|To Build Search Indexes]
row.PlainText: Managing Search Within Acumatica ERP, users can search wikis and various system entities, thus making the process of looking up for data quick and easy. This chapter describes the main points in search configuration and management. In This Chapter Search in Acumatica ERPTo Build Search Indexes

row.column: Search in Acumatica ERPWithin Acumatica ERP, users can perform searches in help, wikis, and various entities , such as vendors, customers, invoices, and contracts. To make the process quick and accurate, Acumatica ERP uses semantic search and search indexes. Semantic Search in Acumatica ERP Acumatica ERP uses semantic search through SQL databases that allows the system to identify the key phrases in text or documents, discover similar or related documents, and provide information to explain how documents are similar or related. To employ semantic search in your Acumatica ERP instance, make sure that semantic search functionality is enabled in your SQL server. In Microsoft SQL Server, the semantic search functionality is disabled by default. Enable the functionality, as described in Enabling Semantic Search for Microsoft SQL Server in Acumatica ERP Installation Guide. In MySQL Server, the semantic search functionality is enabled by default. Search Indexes The search indexes are used to accelerate searching in Acumatica ERP. When users perform the day-to-day operations, such as adding new documents or updating customer accounts, the new information is added to the appropriate search indexes automatically. You need to rebuild the search indexes in the following cases: After you have upgraded your Acumatica ERP system from a version that did not include the search indexes After you have installed an Acumatica ERP tenant with demo data For detailed procedure, see To Build Search Indexes. The list of indexed entities, excluding the wikis, is available on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM209500|SM209500]) Rebuild Full-Text Entity Index (SM209500) form. The built-in help wikis are indexed automatically. The wikis created in your system are not indexes automatically; you must add search indexes for such wikis manually, as described To Add a Wiki. Wiki search indexes are not displayed on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM209500|SM209500]) Rebuild Full-Text Entity Index form. Known Limitations to Search Queries A semantic search does not find related entities if the search query includes word breakers, such as AND or FOR . For example, suppose that you want to find related entities by using a description as a search query. The description includes at least one word breaker, so in this case, the search returns no results.

After you have upgraded your system from a version that did not include the search indexes, as described in [HelpRoot_Install\Upgrading_Acumatica|Updating Acumatica ERP], you use the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_95_00|Rebuild Full-Text Entity Index] ([~/?ScreenId=SM209500|SM209500]) form to build search indexes. For more information on search indexes, see [HelpRoot_Administration\SM__mng_Search|Managing Search]. ==To Build Search Indexes== #Open the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_95_00|Rebuild Full-Text Entity Index] ([~/?ScreenId=SM209500|SM209500]) form. #On the form toolbar, click '''Process All'''. #:The indexing of the data may take some time. The green check mark appears for the indexes after their successful creation. The red appears for the indexes that could not be built. #For each index that could not be built, do the following: #*Select the index, and then click '''Process''' on the form toolbar. #:The system tries to make the index again. #If the problem persists, you can recreate the indexes as follows: ##On the form toolbar, click '''Clear All Indexes'''. ##Repeat Steps 2 and 3 to build indexes anew. #If your system includes custom wikis, build indexes for such wikis. On the form toolbar, click '''Index Custom Articles'''.
The indexes are added to the system. The existing indexes are updated automatically.

To Build Search Indexes After you have upgraded your system from a version that did not include the search indexes, as described in Updating Acumatica ERP, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM209500|SM209500]) Rebuild Full-Text Entity Index (SM209500) form to build search indexes. For more information on search indexes, see Managing Search. To Build Search Indexes Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM209500|SM209500]) Rebuild Full-Text Entity Index (SM209500) form. On the form toolbar, click Process All . The indexing of the data may take some time. The green check mark appears for the indexes after their successful creation. The red appears for the indexes that could not be built. For each index that could not be built, do the following: Select the index, and then click Process on the form toolbar. The system tries to make the index again. If the problem persists, you can recreate the indexes as follows: On the form toolbar, click Clear All Indexes . Repeat Steps 2 and 3 to build indexes anew. If your system includes custom wikis, build indexes for such wikis. On the form toolbar, click Index Custom Articles . The indexes are added to the system. The existing indexes are updated automatically.

Acumatica ERP provides two-factor authentication, so that access to the system is granted only after the user successfully presents to the system additional evidence of authentication in addition to the user credentials (that is, the username and password). At the system level, a system administrator can require two-factor authentication or turn off this authentication (the default setting). In addition, the administrator can specify different settings for individual users with regard to two-factor authentication. If two-factor authentication is required, the user needs to authenticate the sign-in operation by using one of the specified authentication methods.((({S:Warn}This functionality is available only if the ''Two-Factor Authentication'' feature is enabled on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] form. ))) The topics in this chapter contain information you can use as you configure, manage, and use the two-factor authentication. ==In This Chapter==[anchor|#ul_lwn_qdx_ls] *[HelpRoot_Administration\AS__con_Authentication_two_factor|Two-Factor Authentication] *[HelpRoot_Administration\AS__how_Authentication_two_factor|To Configure Two-Factor Authentication] *[HelpRoot_Administration\AS__how_Authentication_two_factor_sign_in|To Sign In with Two-Factor Authentication]

Managing Two-Factor Authentication Acumatica ERP provides two-factor authentication, so that access to the system is granted only after the user successfully presents to the system additional evidence of authentication in addition to the user credentials (that is, the username and password). At the system level, a system administrator can require two-factor authentication or turn off this authentication (the default setting). In addition, the administrator can specify different settings for individual users with regard to two-factor authentication. If two-factor authentication is required, the user needs to authenticate the sign-in operation by using one of the specified authentication methods. This functionality is available only if the Two-Factor Authentication feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form. The topics in this chapter contain information you can use as you configure, manage, and use the two-factor authentication. In This Chapter Two-Factor AuthenticationTo Configure Two-Factor AuthenticationTo Sign In with Two-Factor Authentication

Two-Factor Authentication Acumatica ERP and the Acumatica mobile app provides mechanisms to support two-factor authentication to prevent unauthorized system access. Security-conscious businesses require two-factor authentication to verify user identities before allowing them to access sensitive ERP data. This functionality is available only if the Two-Factor Authentication feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form. Access is granted only after the user successfully presents to the system additional evidence of authentication in addition to the user's credentials (that is, the username and password). At the system level, a system administrator can require two-factor authentication or turn off this authentication (the default setting). In addition, the administrator can specify different settings for individual users with regard to two-factor authentication; user settings take precedence over system-wide settings. If two-factor authentication is required, the user needs to authenticate the sign-in operation by using one of the methods displayed in the following screenshot. By default, when two-factor authentication is enabled, the system uses the push notification method to authenticate the login operation. Push notifications are available only for instances with a valid license. The push notification method of authentication requires the Acumatica app to be set up on a mobile device. You can specify whether the user confirms authentication in one of the following ways: By tapping Approve in Acumatica mobile app push notification. By email. This authentication method will be on the the login screen list if the administrator selects the Allow Email check box on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences (SM201060) form. Via SMS. This authentication method will be in on the the login screen list if the administrator selects the Allow SMS check box on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences form. By generating codes in Acumatica mobile app with the Generate Access Code command. By generating codes on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users (SM201010) or User Profile (SM203010) form. The Two-Factor Authentication Policy section on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences form is used for setting up system-wide two-factor authentication preferences. The settings in this sentence affect all of the company's users that do not have their own settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users form. On the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users form, in the Two-Factor Authentication section, the administrator must select the Override Security Preferences check box in order to override the system default settings and specify the two-factor authentication mode for a specific selected user. (Otherwise, the settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences form will be used.) If two-factor authentication is required for a particular user, the first time that user signs in to the Acumatica mobile app, the system will request the security access code that will be sent to the user's email address when the user signs in to the web version of Acumatica ERP. The mobile app will also require PIN code or biometric verification when the user signs in. By invoking the Generate Access Code command in the account editing menu of the mobile app, the user can generate access codes for two-factor authentication.

At the system level, two-factor authentication can be required or turned off (the default setting). As a system administrator, you can specify different settings for individual users with regard to two-factor authentication; user settings take precedence over system-wide settings. Configuring two-factor authentication involves the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_10_60|Security Preferences] ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) form and either the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_10_10|Users] ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) form or the [HelpRoot_GettingStarted\SM_20_30_10|User Profile] ([~/?ScreenId=SM203010|SM203010]) form. To Configure Two-Factor Authentication At the system level, two-factor authentication can be required or turned off (the default setting). As a system administrator, you can specify different settings for individual users with regard to two-factor authentication; user settings take precedence over system-wide settings. Configuring two-factor authentication involves the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences (SM201060) form and either the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users (SM201010) form or the ([~/?ScreenId=SM203010|SM203010]) User Profile User Profile (SM203010) form. This functionality is available only if the Two-Factor Authentication feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form. Before You Begin Make sure that all users have email addresses properly configured in the system, and that all the necessary actions of sending and receiving emails by schedule are activated. A user will receive an access code by email for the first sign-in after two-factor authentication is enabled for that user. Be sure that your license is activated for the instance. If this license is not activated, two-factor authentication by push notifications cannot be used. For more details, see Preparing Instance: To Activate and License Instance. If your site works via the HTTP protocol, add the following key to the web.config file: <add key="identityServer:allowHttp" value="true" /> . To Configure Two-Factor Authentication If you want to turn on two-factor authentication for all users, on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences (SM201060) form, in the Two-Factor Authentication box, select Required ; save your changes. Skip to Step 4 if there is no need to specify settings for individual users or user types. If you want to turn off two-factor authentication for particular user types, on the ([~/?ScreenId=EP202500|EP202500]) User Types (EP202500) form, select the user type and, on the Login Rules tab, select the Turn Off Two-Factor Authentication check box. If you want to turn on or off two-factor authentication for particular users, on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users (SM201010) form, do the following for each of these users: In the Login box of the Summary area, select a user for whom you want to configure the two-factor authentication. In the Two-Factor Authentication section, select the Override Security Preferences check box. In the Two-Factor Authentication box, select the needed value: Required if you want to turn on two-factor authentication Required for Unknown Devices if you want to turn on two-factor authentication only if a user signs in to Acumatica ERP from a device that has not been used for signing in before None if you want to turn off two-factor authentication If two-factor authentication is enabled for a user in at least one tenant, the user must sign in to all tenants (to which he or she has access) by using two-factor authentication. Save your changes for this user. Before you sign out of the system, generate access codes for at least one user with a system administrator role: On the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users or ([~/?ScreenId=SM203010|SM203010]) User Profile User Profile (SM203010) form, click Generate Access Codes . The system will generate access codes that this user can use if other sign-in methods will not work. Then print or save the list of codes for future use. If you want the system to be able to send access codes by email, on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences form, in the Two-Factor Authentication Policy section, select the Allow Email check box. When a user with two-factor authentication enabled signs in to the system, an access code will be sent to the email address specified for the user on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users form. If you want the system to send access codes by SMS, do the following: Publish the PXVoiceProvider.zip customization (which you can download from the Partner Portal). On the Voice Provider (SM203535) form, specify the appropriate settings of the Twilio account. On the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences form, select the Allow SMS check box in the Two-Factor Authentication Policy section. (This check box appears on the form after you complete the two previous substeps.) Save your changes. When a user with two-factor authentication enabled signs in to the system, an access code will be sent to the mobile phone number specified for the user on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM203010|SM203010]) User Profile User Profile form.

To Sign In with Two-Factor Authentication When two-factor authentication has been enabled, you must register your mobile device or devices to receive confirmation requests as push notifications. That is, you must sign in to the Acumatica server in the mobile app by using an access code. Even if you have signed in to the server before, you must sign in again by using an access code. This must be done once for each mobile device. To Sign In with Two-Factor Authentication On your mobile device, enter your credentials on the Sign-In page. The system sends an access code for the mobile app to the user's email address. If the Acumatica mobile app is not installed on the device, install the app, and create an account for the Acumatica ERP server to which you want to connect. When you sign in to the mobile app, click the Send request to device button on the Sign-In page (as shown in the following screenshot). The system will send a push notification with a code to the registered device. If the message with the access code is not displayed on the Sign-In page, this means that the device was not registered properly, and you need to make sure that the instructions in the previous step have been completed correctly. The Send request to device button Open the push notification and tap Approve (as shown in the following screenshot). You need to confirm approval by using biometric authentication (if it is supported by the device) or by entering your PIN. A sample push notification with an access code You will be signed in to the mobile app automatically. If you cannot receive a push notification, you can use the Use Another Authentication Method link on the Sign-In page. You can do any of the following: Receive an access code by SMS. You can use this method if the sending of SMS messages has been enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences (SM201060) form and the correct mobile phone number has been specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM203010|SM203010]) User Profile User Profile form. When you receive the access code in SMS, enter the code on the Sign-In page. Receive an access code by email. You can use this method if the sending of emails has been enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201060|SM201060]) Security Preferences form and the correct email address is specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users form. When you receive the access code in an email, enter the code on the Welcome screen. Use an existing access code or a code generated by the mobile app. You can use one of codes from the list generated on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users or ([~/?ScreenId=SM203010|SM203010]) User Profile User Profile form. Alternatively, if you are signed in the mobile app, use the Generate Access Code action on the mobile device (see the following screenshot). The Generate Access Code action in the mobile app When you sign in to the system after registration, a push notification with a sign-in request will be sent automatically to the registered mobile devices. You need to approve the request, and sign-in will be performed automatically. The other authentication methods (which are described above) also can be used if push notifications are not available at the moment of sign-in. When you sign in to the mobile app by using an account with two-factor authentication enabled, the app will always request to confirm your identity by using biometric authentication (if it is supported by the device) or by entering your PIN. You can disable push notifications with sign-in requests for a particular device or particular devices by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM201010|SM201010]) Users or ([~/?ScreenId=SM203010|SM203010]) User Profile User Profile form as follows: On the Devices tab, you clear the check box in the Send Confirmation Push column.

row.Content: Acumatica ERP provides functionality that you can use to perform localization to one locale or multiple locales. In this chapter, you can find information on the translation process and the management of locales. ==In This Chapter==[anchor|#ul_bwz_td2_qr] *[HelpRoot_Administration\SM__CON_Locales_and_Languages|Locales and Languages] *[HelpRoot_Administration\SM__CON_Boxes_MultiLanguage|Boxes that Have Multi-Language Support] *[HelpRoot_Administration\SM__CON_Usage_of_UserInput_Translations|Use of User Input Translations] *[HelpRoot_Administration\SM__con_Translation_Process|Translation Process]
row.PlainText: Managing Locales and Languages Acumatica ERP provides functionality that you can use to perform localization to one locale or multiple locales. In this chapter, you can find information on the translation process and the management of locales. In This Chapter Locales and LanguagesBoxes that Have Multi-Language SupportUse of User Input TranslationsTranslation Process

row.column: Locales and Languages Acumatica ERP provides functionality that you can use to localize the system in multiple languages. You can maintain the user interface and wikis in multiple languages if you have multiple locales. The default locale of Acumatica ERP is U.S. English. Localization includes the usage of locale-specific settings and the translation of the strings used on the application interface. Starting with Acumatica ERP 6, you can translate user input to multiple languages and store translations in the database. In this topic, you will read about how locales and languages are handled in the system. Understanding Locales and Languages Acumatica ERP uses the list of locales provided by Microsoft.NET. In most cases, a locale identifier has two parts: The ISO code of the language: The system retrieves the language code from the locale identifier to create a new entity language and associates the language with the locale. Note that the system associates multiple locales with a language if the identifiers of these locales contain the same ISO code of a language. For example, the en-US , en-GB , and en-AU locales are all associated with English, the language whose ISO code is en . You can use these languages to localize user input. The translations can be further used for printing reports and documents. For details, see Enabling Multilingual User Input Enabling Multilingual User Input. The ISO code of the region (or country): The system uses the region code of the identifier to define which resource libraries of the Microsoft .NET Framework to use when it applies region-specific settings, which include the date and time format, the format of numbers (such as the decimal separator and digit grouping), and the writing direction. In the previous example, US , GB , and AU are all ISO codes of the country. In Acumatica ERP, the translations of the user interface and wiki articles are associated with a locale, and the translations of user input are associated with a language. Adding New Locales to the System When Acumatica ERP is installed, one locale (U.S. English) is present by default. You can add other locales on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200550|SM200550]) System Locales (SM200550) form. For the detailed procedure, see To Add a New Locale. When you activate multiple locales, a user may select his or her preferred locale on the Sign-In page before signing in the system. A newly added locale is inactive by default, which means the system does not display it in the list of locales on the Sign-In page. For an inactive locale, you can override locale preferences (region-specific settings). Also, you can use the Acumatica ERP translation functionality to translate the interface elements for the locale. For details, see Translation Process. After you activate the locale, it becomes available for selection on the Sign-In page. Once a user selects the locale and signs in to Acumatica ERP, the system displays the localized interface and applies the specified locale preferences by using the resource libraries provided for the selected locale by the Microsoft .NET Framework. Also, you can print localized versions of reports if you have translated the reports' strings for the locale you are currently signed in with. For details, see Use of User Input Translations. When a user with a right to edit wiki articles is signed in with a locale, he or she can create locale-specific versions of the wiki articles. For details, see Translating Wiki Articles in Translation Process. Enabling Multilingual User Input Starting with Acumatica ERP 6, you can translate user input to multiple languages and store translations in the database. For example, you can enter descriptions of General Ledger accounts in multiple languages and then print a localized version of the trial balance report with the descriptions of accounts in the language of the locale you are currently signed in with. To make this functionality available, you perform the following steps: If the needed locales are not defined in the system, you add and activate them on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200550|SM200550]) System Locales form. For step-by-step instructions, see To Add a New Locale. The system retrieves the ISO codes of languages from the locales (active and inactive) and forms the initial list of languages that you will use to define a set of languages to translate user input to. The system associates multiple locales with a language if the identifiers of these locales contain the same ISO code of a language. You click the Set Up Languages button on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200550|SM200550]) System Locales form toolbar that invokes the Languages dialog box. In the dialog box, you specify the languages in which you are going to translate user input and define the default language. For details, see the Setting Up Languages Setting Up Languages section in this topic. Once you have finished making the functionality available, you can translate user input for the boxes that have multi-language support. A link (for example, ) is displayed next to these text boxes in the system. Clicking this link invokes the Translations dialog box (described in the Translations Dialog Box topic of the Interface Guide). You enter translations for each language, close the dialog box, and click Save on the form toolbar. You can also add translations for text in the rich text editor (for example, a description of a stock item on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form). On the formatting toolbar, you select languages for which you would like to add a translation one after another, enter a translation, and click Save on the form toolbar. The translation tool that is described in this section can also be used for translating filter tabs (see To Translate Filter Tab Captions) and generic inquiry elements, such as column captions in the results grid (see To Translate Column Captions for a Generic Inquiry) and parameter display names (see To Translate Parameter Display Names for a Generic Inquiry). For the list of boxes with this support, see Boxes that Have Multi-Language Support. You can upload translations from a file for those entities (such as account classes, ledgers, and financial periods) that support integration with Excel. You can also import values to these text boxes and export values from them by using integration scenarios. For details, see Multi-Language Fields in Import and Export Scenarios. Setting Up Languages In Acumatica ERP, a language can be marked as the default, an alternative, or not used in the localization of user input. When you specify the default language, multi-language support is enabled for the supported text boxes in the system. The default language and alternative languages form the list of languages for which you can provide translations in the Translations dialog box. To define the set of languages to translate user input to, do the following: Click the Set Up Languages button on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200550|SM200550]) System Locales form toolbar to invoke the Languages dialog box. The dialog box contains the list of languages, represented by their ISO codes, that the system retrieved from the list of locales (active and inactive). In the Default Language box, select the ISO code of the language that you want to mark as the default. The default language must be associated with an active locale. In the table below the box, select the unlabeled check box for the languages you want to mark as alternatives and clear this check box for those languages that you want to exclude from the localization of user input. If a language is associated with an inactive locale, the system does not display it in the Translations dialog box. Once you apply the settings, in the table on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200550|SM200550]) System Locales form, you can view which locales are associated with languages that are the default, alternatives, or not used in localization by adding to the table the Alternative Language and Default Language columns, which are hidden by default. After you set up languages, you can proceed with translating user input for the text boxes that have multi-language support. Disabling Locales and Multilingual User Input If you do not need a particular locale anymore, you can clear the Active check box for this locale on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200550|SM200550]) System Locales form. The system then excludes this locale from the list of available locales (the Locale box) on the following forms: The Sign-In page Report forms ([~/?ScreenId=SM204003|SM204003]) Notification Templates (SM204003) ([~/?ScreenId=AR201000|AR201000]) Customer Classes (AR201000) ([~/?ScreenId=AR303000|AR303000]) Customers (AR303000) ([~/?ScreenId=AP201000|AP201000]) Vendor Classes (AP201000) ([~/?ScreenId=AP303000|AP303000]) Vendors (AP303000) The system stores the translations you have added for the deactivated locale, so you can activate it again and view the associated translations of the user interface and wiki pages. If you deactivate all the locales but one, the system will not display the Locale box on the forms listed above. If you do not need to translate user input in a particular language, you do one of the following by using the Set Up Languages dialog box on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200550|SM200550]) System Locales form: If the language was marked as an alternative, you clear the unlabeled check box for the language. If the language was marked as the default, you select another language in the Default Language box and clear the unlabeled check box in the table for those languages that you want to exclude from the localization of user input. The system stores the translations you have added for the excluded language, so you can activate it again and view the associated translations of the user input.

Once you have enabled multilingual user input, the system displays a link with a language ISO code next to the supported text boxes in the system. When you click the link, the '''Translations''' dialog box appears, where you can enter translations. For a description of the dialog box, see [HelpRoot_Interface\UIG__CON_TranslationBoxes|Translations Dialog Box].{br}
By default, the system supports multilingual user input for the boxes listed in this topic. You can expand this list by means of customization. Also, if the <tt>PXDBString</tt> attribute for a box from the list was customized in the earlier versions, after upgrade to Acumatica ERP 6 the box will not have multi-language support. For details, see [HelpRoot_Dev_Customization\CG_Platform_Framework_CS_DACExt_FieldAttributes|Customization of Field Attributes in DAC Extensions] in the Customization Guide.{br}
In this topic, you will find lists, broken down by module, of the boxes that have multi-language support.{br}{TOC} ==Projects Module== You can localize values for the following text boxes in the Projects module:[anchor|#_e287ab8c-5dbb-4b4a-93fc-6d25caf601cf] *The '''Invoice Description''' column on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\PM_20_70_00|Billing Rules] ([~/?ScreenId=PM207000|PM207000]) form *The '''Description''' box on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\PM_30_10_00|Projects] ([~/?ScreenId=PM301000|PM301000]) form *The '''Description''' box in the Summary area of the [HelpRoot_FormReference\PM_30_20_00|Project Tasks] ([~/?ScreenId=PM302000|PM302000]) form *The '''Description''' box in the Summary area of the [HelpRoot_FormReference\PM_20_10_00|Account Groups] ([~/?ScreenId=PM201000|PM201000]) form *The '''Description''' column on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\PM_20_95_00|Cost Codes] ([~/?ScreenId=PM209500|PM209500]) form

Boxes that Have Multi-Language Support Once you have enabled multilingual user input, the system displays a link with a language ISO code next to the supported text boxes in the system. When you click the link, the Translations dialog box appears, where you can enter translations. For a description of the dialog box, see Translations Dialog Box. Also, if the PXDBString attribute for a box from the list was customized in the earlier versions, after upgrade to Acumatica ERP 6 the box will not have multi-language support. For details, see Customization of Field Attributes in DAC Extensions in the Customization Guide.
