In the Sequence box, specify the whole or decimal number that defines the sequential position of the wiki on the Help dashboard. Acumatica ERP doesn't verify the sequence number that you specify for each wiki. We recommend that you use different sequence numbers for different wikis to avoid unexpected results. Optional: In the Default Article box, select the article to be displayed by default when a user clicks Explore on the wiki card on the Help dashboard. If no article is selected here, the first article of the selected wiki is displayed by default. On the Wiki Settings tab, in the Dashboard Description box, type an explanation of the content of the wiki, which will be used on the wiki card on the Help dashboard. In the description box, you can enter 255 characters, but we recommend that you enter no more than 160 characters so that your description fits the wiki card displayed on the Help dashboard. In the Classic UI section, do the following: In the Site Map Location box, select the node of the site map in which the wiki will be located. In the Site Map Title box, type the title of wiki on the site map. On the Wiki Settings tab, apply the appropriate style options for the wiki by doing the following: In the Style box of the Look and Feel section, select the prepared file with the CSS styles intended for displaying the articles of the wiki in a browser. If you specify no file, the browser-specific default styles will be used. In the Print Style box, select the prepared file with the CSS styles that define how a printed article of the wiki should look. If no file is specified, the browser-specific default styles will be used. In the Article Type box, select the type of articles that will make up the content of the wiki. The following options are available: Article : The basic type of articles. This type of articles may contain various content (text, tables, graphics, and links). Usually this type is used for Help articles. KB Article : The type of article especially designed for Knowledge Base articles. This type of articles may contain the same content as basic articles. Additionally, users can rate the articles and leave their feedback for a particular article, which gives you the ability to collect statistics and information on how helpful the articles are. Skip the Template , Print Template , Header , and Footer boxes until you create wiki templates. You can apply templates to the wiki only after you create them for the selected wiki. For more information, see To Create a Wiki Template and To Apply Templates to a Wiki. Optional: In the Miscellaneous section of the Wiki Settings tab, do the following: In the Default Site Map Tag box, select the tag to be used by default for new articles. (This step can be performed later, when at least one tag has been created.) In the Public Virtual Path box, specify the web address of the wiki on a local website to be used for access outside of your local network. On the form toolbar, click Save to save the settings you've specified for the wiki so far. Only if you have selected the node of the site map in which the wiki will be located in the Site Map Location box (which causes the system to generate user roles and access rights for the selected wiki), on the Access Rights tab, configure the access rights for the wiki by doing the following in the table: In the Access Rights column of the first row, select the proper option for the selected role. The following options, listed from the most restrictive access rights to the broadest ones, are available: These access rights apply to all items (folders and articles) within the wiki unless you set different access rights for particular items within it; for more information, see Wiki Access Management. Revoked : For users with the role, doesn't allow any access to the wiki and the articles and folders within it, including viewing these items. View Only : Allows users with the role to view all published articles and folders within the wiki. Edit : Allows users with the role to edit the articles and folders in the wiki. Insert : Allows users with the role to edit and create new articles and folders in the wiki. Publish : Allows users with the role to edit, create, and directly publish articles and folders (or initiate the approval process for publishing, if this approval is required for the wiki) in the wiki. Delete : Allows users with the role to delete articles and folders within the wiki, in addition to the rights at lower levels of access. Repeat the previous substep for each additional row with a role listed. On the form toolbar, click Save to change the access rights for the roles. Optional: On the Tags tab, create the list of tags to be used to mark the versions of articles in the wiki. To create the tags, do the following: Tags can be created at any time and are not required for initial wiki setup. In the table toolbar, click Add Row to add a new blank row to the table. In the Description box, type a descriptive name for the tag. Repeat the two previous substeps for each tag you want to add. On the form toolbar, click Save . ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005])

A template is a wiki article with a specific ID identifying it as a template and with wiki markups defined in the text area of the '''Content''' tab. You create the template in the wiki you want to apply it to. To create a template, follow the steps below: ==To Create a Wiki Template==[anchor|#_d17b3555-740f-43c9-bc55-ac17a8ce5ef2] #Open the wiki in the node that you specified for it. #On the wiki toolbar, click '''Add New Article''' to open the Wiki Editor form for a new article or folder. #On the '''Content''' tab, in the '''Article ID''' box, specify the ID for the template as follows: #*If this is an article template or print template, type <tt>ContainerTemplate:</tt> and then specify a text string identifying the template; do not use any spaces in the line. #*If this is a header or footer template, type <tt>GenTemplate:</tt> and then specify a text string identifying the template; do not use any spaces in the line. #In the '''Name''' box, type the name of the template. You can use the same value in the '''Article ID''' and '''Name''' boxes. #In the '''Parent Folder''' box, select the folder in which you want to save the template from the list of the available ones. #:((({S:Warn}We recommend that you store templates in their own separate folder of the selected wiki. For more information about creating a folder, see [HelpRoot_Administration\DM__how_Wiki_Creating_a_Folder|To Create a Folder]. ))) #Clear the '''Hold''' check box to cause the wiki to have the ''Published'' status. #In the text area at the bottom of the '''Content''' tab, depending on the type of the template, specify the code that will define the style and contents of the article, the printed article, the header, or the footer. For more information about wiki markup, see [HelpRoot_Administration\DM__con_Wiki_Using_Wiki_Markup|Wiki Markup Reference]. #On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click '''Save'''.

To Create a Wiki Template A template is a wiki article with a specific ID identifying it as a template and with wiki markups defined in the text area of the Content tab. You create the template in the wiki you want to apply it to. To create a template, follow the steps below: To Create a Wiki Template Open the wiki in the node that you specified for it. On the wiki toolbar, click Add New Article to open the Wiki Editor form for a new article or folder. On the Content tab, in the Article ID box, specify the ID for the template as follows: If this is an article template or print template, type ContainerTemplate: and then specify a text string identifying the template; do not use any spaces in the line. If this is a header or footer template, type GenTemplate: and then specify a text string identifying the template; do not use any spaces in the line. In the Name box, type the name of the template. You can use the same value in the Article ID and Name boxes. In the Parent Folder box, select the folder in which you want to save the template from the list of the available ones. We recommend that you store templates in their own separate folder of the selected wiki. For more information about creating a folder, see To Create a Folder. Clear the Hold check box to cause the wiki to have the Published status. In the text area at the bottom of the Content tab, depending on the type of the template, specify the code that will define the style and contents of the article, the printed article, the header, or the footer. For more information about wiki markup, see Wiki Markup Reference. On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save .

You use the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_20_05|Wiki] ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) form to apply the templates you have defined to the wiki you select. ==Before You Proceed== Make sure that you have created the templates for the wiki. For details, see [HelpRoot_Administration\DM__how_Wiki_Creating_Template|To Create a Wiki Template].[anchor|#_d20d793a-635b-4fd1-8754-42511e563d16] ==To Apply Templates to a Wiki==[anchor|#_04af2c8d-1757-48f9-845b-8cd9a1a94270] #Open the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_20_05|Wiki] ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) form. #In the '''General''' section, select a wiki by its identifier in the '''ID''' box. #On the '''Wiki Settings''' tab, in the '''Template''' box, select the template that has been defined for the articles in the wiki. #In the '''Print Template''' box, select the template that has been defined for printing purposes. #In the '''Header''' box, select the template that has been defined for the header. #In the '''Footer''' box, select the template that has been defined for the footer. #On the form toolbar, click '''Save'''.

To Apply Templates to a Wiki You use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form to apply the templates you have defined to the wiki you select. Before You Proceed Make sure that you have created the templates for the wiki. For details, see To Create a Wiki Template. To Apply Templates to a Wiki Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the General section, select a wiki by its identifier in the ID box. On the Wiki Settings tab, in the Template box, select the template that has been defined for the articles in the wiki. In the Print Template box, select the template that has been defined for printing purposes. In the Header box, select the template that has been defined for the header. In the Footer box, select the template that has been defined for the footer. On the form toolbar, click Save .

To Display and Hide a Wiki in the UI If you want to make a wiki available for other users, you can add a card for it to the Help dashboard; you can also hide a card for a wiki from the Help dashboard if it is already displayed there. You might want to display a wiki card on the Help dashboard if any users in your system may use the Acumatica ERP UI. To display or hide a wiki, you use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. To Display a Wiki in the UI Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the Summary area of the form, in the ID box of the General section, select the identifier of the wiki that you want to make visible on the Help dashboard. In the Modern UI section, select the Show on Help Dashboard check box to display a card for the selected wiki on the Help dashboard. In the Sequence box, specify the whole or decimal number that defines the sequential position of the wiki on the Help dashboard. Acumatica ERP doesn't verify the sequence number that you specify for each wiki. We recommend that you use different sequence numbers for different wikis to avoid unexpected results. Optional: In the Default Article box, select the article to be displayed by default when a user clicks Explore on the wiki card on the Help dashboard. If no article is selected here, the first article of the selected wiki is displayed by default. On the Wiki Settings tab, in the Dashboard Description box, type an explanation of the content of the wiki, which will be used on the wiki card on the Help dashboard. In the description box, you can enter 255 characters, but we recommend that you enter no more than 160 characters so that your description fits the wiki card displayed on the Help dashboard. In the Classic UI section, do the following: In the Site Map Location box, select the node of the site map in which the wiki will be located. You specify the site map location of the selected wiki to make it available for use in the system. This step is necessary. In the Site Map Title box, type the title of wiki on the site map. On the form toolbar, click Save . To Hide a Wiki in the UI Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the Summary area of the form, in the ID box of the General section, select the identifier of the wiki that you want to hide from the Help dashboard. In the Modern UI section, clear the Show on Help Dashboard check box to hide the card for the selected wiki on the Help dashboard. In the Classic UI section, clear the Site Map Location box to delete the selected wiki from the node of the site map. On the form toolbar, click Save .

''Categories'' are distinct classes that divide wiki articles into types. You can use the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_05_23|Wiki Categories] ([~/?ScreenId=SM200523|SM200523]) form to define categories for wiki articles and manage articles included in a category.{br}
When you create a new article, you can select one category or multiple categories for it, based on the article content. You can assign one category to articles in different wikis. When you perform a search, you can select the category of the articles to be searched. ==To Add a New Category== You can add a category on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_05_23|Wiki Categories] ([~/?ScreenId=SM200523|SM200523]) form as follows:[anchor|#ol_a1w_c2x_ls] #Open the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_05_23|Wiki Categories] form. #In the '''Category ID''' box of the Summary area, type a short name for the new category. #In the '''Category Name''' box, type a more descriptive name for the new category. #On the form toolbar, click '''Save'''.
==To Assign Categories to Articles== You can assign articles to a particular category on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_05_23|Wiki Categories] ([~/?ScreenId=SM200523|SM200523]) form as follows:[anchor|#ol_lzf_lhv_xk] #Open the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_05_23|Wiki Categories] form #In the '''Category ID''' box of the Summary area, select the category you want to add the articles to. #On the table toolbar, click '''Add Row'''. #In the '''Article ID''' box, select an article. #Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for every article you want to add to the category. #On the form toolbar, click '''Save'''.
You can also assign categories to a particular article that you’re editing. You do this by using the [HelpRoot_FormReference\DM__con_Wiki_Wiki_Editor_Form_for_Articles|Wiki Editor Form for Articles] (which opens when you open an article and click '''Edit Current Article''') as follows:[anchor|#ol_hwn_lhv_xk] #Open the article. #On the help toolbar, click '''Edit Current Article'''. #On the '''Category''' tab, click '''Add Row''' on the table toolbar. #In the '''Category ID''' column, select the category. #Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for every category you want to add to the article. #On the form toolbar, click '''Save'''.

To Use Categories in Wikis Categories are distinct classes that divide wiki articles into types. You can use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200523|SM200523]) Wiki Categories (SM200523) form to define categories for wiki articles and manage articles included in a category. When you create a new article, you can select one category or multiple categories for it, based on the article content. You can assign one category to articles in different wikis. When you perform a search, you can select the category of the articles to be searched. To Add a New Category You can add a category on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200523|SM200523]) Wiki Categories (SM200523) form as follows: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200523|SM200523]) Wiki Categories form. In the Category ID box of the Summary area, type a short name for the new category. In the Category Name box, type a more descriptive name for the new category. On the form toolbar, click Save . To Assign Categories to Articles You can assign articles to a particular category on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200523|SM200523]) Wiki Categories (SM200523) form as follows: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200523|SM200523]) Wiki Categories form In the Category ID box of the Summary area, select the category you want to add the articles to. On the table toolbar, click Add Row . In the Article ID box, select an article. Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for every article you want to add to the category. On the form toolbar, click Save . You can also assign categories to a particular article that you're editing. You do this by using the Wiki Editor Form for Articles (which opens when you open an article and click Edit Current Article ) as follows: Open the article. On the help toolbar, click Edit Current Article . On the Category tab, click Add Row on the table toolbar. In the Category ID column, select the category. Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for every category you want to add to the article. On the form toolbar, click Save .

You can use the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_05_24|Wiki Products] ([~/?ScreenId=SM200524|SM200524]) form to define products for wiki articles and manage the articles that apply to a product. ==To Add a New Product== You can add product by using the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_05_24|Wiki Products] form as follows:[anchor|#ol_m4l_hsv_xk] #On the '''Configuration''' tab, click '''Document Management'''. In the left pane, click '''Configure''' > '''Wiki Products'''. #In the '''Product ID''' box of the Summary area, type a short name for the new product. #In the '''Product Name''' box, type a descriptive name for the new product. #On the form toolbar, click '''Save'''.
==To Apply Products to Articles== You can assign articles to a particular product on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_05_24|Wiki Products] form as follows:[anchor|#ol_lzf_lhv_xk] #On the '''Configuration''' tab, click '''Document Management'''. In the left pane, click '''Configure''' > '''Wiki Articles By Product'''. #In the '''Product ID''' box of the Summary area, select the product. #On the table toolbar, click '''Add Row'''. #In the '''Article ID''' box, select an article that applies to the product. #Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for every article that applies to the product. #On the form toolbar, click '''Save'''.
You can also select products that a particular article that you’re editing applies to. You do this by using the [HelpRoot_FormReference\DM__con_Wiki_Wiki_Editor_Form_for_Articles|Wiki Editor Form for Articles] as follows:[anchor|#ol_hwn_lhv_xk] #Open the article. #On the help toolbar, click '''Edit Current Article''' to open the article for editing. #On the '''Product''' tab, click '''Add Row''' on the table toolbar. #In the '''Product ID''' column, select the product. #Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for every product the article applies to. #On the form toolbar, click '''Save'''.

To Use Products in Wikis In wikis, you can group articles based on the product the articles apply to. When you create a new article, you can apply it to one product or multiple products, based on the article content. When you perform a search, you can select the product that the articles you're seeking apply to. You can use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200524|SM200524]) Wiki Products (SM200524) form to define products for wiki articles and manage the articles that apply to a product. To Add a New Product You can add product by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200524|SM200524]) Wiki Products form as follows: On the Configuration tab, click Document Management . In the left pane, click Configure Wiki Products . In the Product ID box of the Summary area, type a short name for the new product. In the Product Name box, type a descriptive name for the new product. On the form toolbar, click Save . To Apply Products to Articles You can assign articles to a particular product on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM200524|SM200524]) Wiki Products form as follows: On the Configuration tab, click Document Management . In the left pane, click Configure Wiki Articles By Product . In the Product ID box of the Summary area, select the product. On the table toolbar, click Add Row . In the Article ID box, select an article that applies to the product. Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for every article that applies to the product. On the form toolbar, click Save . You can also select products that a particular article that you're editing applies to. You do this by using the Wiki Editor Form for Articles as follows: Open the article. On the help toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the article for editing. On the Product tab, click Add Row on the table toolbar. In the Product ID column, select the product. Repeat Steps 3 and 4 for every product the article applies to. On the form toolbar, click Save .

Acumatica Wiki stores the versions of wiki articles, so you can track who made what changes and when. This capability provides the means to revert to a previous version. ((({S:Warn}By default, article versioning is turned on. ))) ==To Control Versions of an Article == For a wiki, you can define whether the articles in the wiki should be versioned by default. This feature makes it easy to track changes and provides a “safety net“ if undesirable changes have been made.{br}
By default, version control for wiki articles is turned on. To control versioning for a particular article, do the following:[anchor|#ol_jfs_l2x_ls] #Open the article. #On the wiki toolbar, click '''Edit Current Article''' to open the Wiki Editor form. #On the '''Properties''' tab, do one of the following: #*Select the '''Versioned''' check box to maintain versions. After that, each time the article is edited and saved, a new version of it will be created. #*Clear the '''Versioned''' check box to not store versions. If the article is new, only one version of it will exist in the system. If the article already has multiple versions, only the last version will be updated when you save it after making changes. #Click '''Save'''.
For a versioned article, you can use the '''History''' tab of the Wiki Editor form to do the following: [anchor|#ul_mgs_l2x_ls] *View who edited it and when *Compare any two versions and view all changes *Delete selected versions *Replace it with any previous version
For more information, see [HelpRoot_Administration\DM__how_Wiki_Comparing_Article_Versions|To Compare Wiki Article Versions].((({S:Warn}The system stores all versions of files attached to the wiki articles. For more information, see [HelpRoot_Administration\DM__How_Tracking_Files|To Manage Files] )))

To Track Changes in Wiki Articles Acumatica Wiki stores the versions of wiki articles, so you can track who made what changes and when. This capability provides the means to revert to a previous version. By default, article versioning is turned on. To Control Versions of an Article For a wiki, you can define whether the articles in the wiki should be versioned by default. This feature makes it easy to track changes and provides a "safety net" if undesirable changes have been made. By default, version control for wiki articles is turned on. To control versioning for a particular article, do the following: Open the article. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the Wiki Editor form. On the Properties tab, do one of the following: Select the Versioned check box to maintain versions. After that, each time the article is edited and saved, a new version of it will be created. Clear the Versioned check box to not store versions. If the article is new, only one version of it will exist in the system. If the article already has multiple versions, only the last version will be updated when you save it after making changes. Click Save . For a versioned article, you can use the History tab of the Wiki Editor form to do the following: View who edited it and when Compare any two versions and view all changes Delete selected versions Replace it with any previous version For more information, see To Compare Wiki Article Versions. The system stores all versions of files attached to the wiki articles. For more information, see To Manage Files

To Compare Wiki Article Versions When you work with an Acumatica ERP wiki, you can store the history of each article so that you can answer any questions about who changed what and when the changes occurred. Not only can you compare versions, but you can also revert to previous ones. If you open an article by using the Wiki Editor form, you can find information related to the article history on the following tabs of the form: On the Content tab, you can view the current status of the article and the date of publication (if the article has the Published status). On the Properties tab, you can see the date the article was created, the user name of the creator, the date it was modified last, and the user name of the person who modified it. On the History tab, you can see the list of article versions, view any of the versions, and compare two selected versions. This tab is described more fully in the following sections. To View the History of an Article The History tab (shown in the following screenshot) contains a list of the article versions and the table toolbar, which has custom buttons to help you work with versions. Article Version History Table Toolbar The table toolbar includes standard buttons and buttons specific to this table. For the list of standard buttons, see Table Toolbar. The table-specific buttons, available only for the wiki of Knowledge Base type, are listed below. Button Description Compare Enables you to compare the versions. Select one version as the source (by selecting the Source Version check box) and another as the target (by selecting the Compare check box), and then click Compare on the toolbar. See the following section for more information on comparing versions. For more information, see the Comparing Versions section of this article. View Version Opens the selected version for viewing. Publish Publishes a specific version. Select the version and then click Publish on the table toolbar. Revert to Version Causes the article to revert to the version you have selected in the list. Table Columns Column Description Source The check box you select to use this version as the source for comparison. Compare The check box you select to use this version as the target for comparison. Version ID The identifier of the version. Created By The user who created the version. Creation Time The date of the creation of the version. Username The user who approved the version, if the version was approved. Approval Time The date of approval, if the version was approved. Language The language of the version. Published The read-only check box that indicated that the selected version of the article was published. To Compare Versions After you have selected a source version and a target version, click Compare to view the Compare Versions form, which consists of two panes. The version selected as the source is displayed in the left pane, and the version selected as the target is shown in the right pane. Compare Versions Form Text that was deleted from the source (left pane) version is highlighted in red, and text inserted into the target (right pane) version is highlighted in green. Lines that have changed in any way are highlighted in blue in both panes. To view the statistics of the versions being compared, click Statistics on the form toolbar, which opens the Statistics dialog box. Article Statistics The Statistics dialog box includes the following information: The dates of the versions The number of words in each version The number of characters in each version (both with and without spaces) The number of lines updated, added, and deleted The number of characters updated, added, and deleted

To Make a Wiki Article Visible in Acumatica ERPYou can make a wiki article that was created on Self-Service Portal visible in Acumatica ERP as well by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form, as described in this topic. (For the procedure that describes how to add a new wiki, see To Add a Wiki.) At a later time, you can remove the visibility of the wiki article that you made visible in Acumatica ERP. To Make a Wiki Article Visible in Acumatica ERPOpen the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the Summary area, do the following: In the ID field, select the ID of the wiki that contains the article to be displayed in Acumatica ERP. In the Name box, type the name of the wiki that will be displayed in Acumatica ERP. In the Site Map Location box, select the node of the site map where the wiki will be located. In the Site Map Title box, type the wiki title on the site map. On the form toolbar, click Save to save the settings you have specified for the wiki so far. Configure access rights for the wiki, as described in Wiki Access Management. Sign out from your Acumatica ERP instance, and then sign in again to view the wiki in the main menu. If you have not done it before, create an article that you want to share in the wiki. The article can be created either in Self-Service Portal or in Acumatica ERP. For a procedure that describes how to add a new wiki article, see To Add an Article. Now you can view the same wiki article both in Acumatica ERP and on Self-Service Portal. To Hide a Wiki From the Acumatica ERP Main Menu Open the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202005|SM202005]) Wiki (SM202005) form. In the ID box, select the wiki that you want to hide from the main menu. In the Site Map Location box, delete the location. On the form toolbar, click Save to remove the wiki from the Acumatica ERP main menu. Reload the webpage in the browser to apply changes in the site map of Acumatica ERP.

To Search Wikis This article describes what searches are available in Acumatica Wiki and how to perform the searches. When you search wikis, you can do a quick search or a full-text search. To perform a search, you can use the Search box (in the navigation pane) and the Search form. For more information on searching in Acumatica ERP, see Search. To Perform a Quick Search When you perform a quick search, the system searches article properties, such as article IDs, categories, names, summaries, and keywords. It does not search the text of articles. For each article, a wiki author can specify a concise summary, an appropriate category (such as reference, overview, or procedure ), and a list of keywords, so that wiki users can quickly find the information they need, even if they do a quick search. To perform a quick search, do the following: In the navigation pane, in the Search box, type a word, a part of a word, or a phrase you're searching for. Click Search . On the Search form, click All Wikis to open the ([~/?ScreenId=SE000040|SE000040]) Search Form (SE000040). On the form, you will see a list of articles in all wikis whose properties contain the search word or phrase you entered in Step 1. Optional: Click the All Wikis arrow and select a wiki to see a list of articles in the selected wiki whose properties contain the search word or phrase you entered in Step 1. Optional: If you selected a particular wiki, click Advanced and then select check boxes for the wiki-specific categories you want the system to search. (This option is unavailable for the All Wikis scope.) To Perform a Full-Text Search For a full-text search, the system searches article properties as well as the full text of articles. The full-text search takes longer and may return articles that do not contain the information you hope to find. To ease the process of finding the required information, start by searching for a more specific word or phrase and then search for broader words or phrases if needed. To perform a full-text search, do the following: In the navigation pane, in the Search box, type the word, part of a word, or phrase you're searching for. Click Search . On the Search form, click All Wikis to open the ([~/?ScreenId=SE000040|SE000040]) Search Form with the list of articles in all wikis whose properties contain the search word you entered. Optional: On the Search form, click the All Wikis arrow and then select a particular wiki to search within it, or select All Wikis to again search in all wikis. This step defines the scope of the search. Select the Full-text search check box. Optional: If you selected a particular wiki, click Advanced and then select check boxes for the wiki-specific categories you want the system to search. (This option is unavailable for the All Wikis scope.) Click Go to start the search.

row.Content: To print any wiki article, do the following:[anchor|#_j4d_gpd_rg] #Open the article you want to print. #On the wiki toolbar, click '''Print'''. #Follow the necessary steps, depending on your browser, to print the article.
row.PlainText: To Print an Article To print any wiki article, do the following: Open the article you want to print. On the wiki toolbar, click Print . Follow the necessary steps, depending on your browser, to print the article.

row.column: To Edit Article Text In Acumatica Wiki, you can use the Wiki Editor form to edit the entire article—its text and properties. Alternatively, you can edit a section of the article or the entire text of the article. To format the text, you use wiki markup, an easy-to-understand syntax that uses special wiki markup elements. You can manually type the wiki markup or click the buttons on the Formatting toolbar to have the system insert markup elements for you. For more information, see Wiki Markup Reference. To Edit the Article and Its Properties You can edit the entire article and its properties by using the Wiki Editor form for the article. To open the Wiki Editor form, click Edit on the wiki toolbar. For more information, see Wiki Editor Form for Articles. To Edit a Section To edit an article section, which consists of the text beneath a heading until the next same-level heading, do the following: Open the wiki article you want to edit. Click Edit to the right of the section heading. Edit the section text. You cannot edit article properties when you're editing a section. On the formatting toolbar, click Save to save your changes or click Cancel to exit the Wiki Editor form without saving changes.

To Add a Link You can create links to places in the current article, to other articles in the same wiki, and to external websites. These links help users quickly access additional information they might need. To Navigate Within an Article With a lengthy article, you might want to give users the ability to quickly navigate within the article. To do this, you first insert anchors to mark the beginnings of sections and other positions in the article to which you want to redirect users. You then insert anchor links, which users can click to easily navigate to the defined anchors. To define an anchor, do the following: Open the article. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the article in the Wiki Editor form. Click the place within the article where you want to create the anchor. Add the anchor by using the following general syntax: [Anchor|# AnchorID ] where AnchorID is the unique identifier you define for the anchor within the article. It can include any combination of numbers and uppercase and lowercase letters. For example, you can use sequential numbers or abbreviated versions of section names as IDs. You can create as many anchors as you like in the article, but each Anchor ID must be unique. After you have added the anchor, you can insert as many links to the anchor as you need. To insert an anchor link, do the following: With the article still open in the Wiki Editor form, click the place within the article where you want to add the anchor link. Add the anchor link by using the following syntax: [# AnchorID | LinkText ] where AnchorID is the identifier that you defined for the anchor, and LinkText is the text to be displayed as the link. The user clicks this link to navigate to the anchor. For example, to enable users to return to the top of the article from a place within the article, create an anchor at the top of an article by adding the following syntax at the beginning of the article: [Anchor|#Top] Then add the following syntax to the article in the place where you want to create the link to the top of the article: [#Top|Return to the top] Now, each time users click the Return to the top link, they navigate to the top of the article. To Add Links to Articles and Websites You use wiki links to give users the ability to quickly access other articles within the Acumatica ERP instance. To add a link to another article, do the following: Open the article to which you want to add the link. Open the article for editing. Do one of the following: On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the entire article in the Wiki Editor form. Click Edit to the right of the section to which you want to add the link. On the formatting toolbar, click Link . This opens the Wiki Link Editor dialog box. In the Wiki Link Editor dialog box, specify the link parameters: To configure a link to another article, do the following: In the Link Type box under the Wiki text box, select Article . In the box to the right of the Link Type box, select the article you want to add a link to. Optional: In the Caption box, type the text of the link, which the user will click to navigate to the article. To configure a link to an external web site, do the following: In the Link Type box under the Wiki text box, select URL . In the box to the right of the Link Type box, type or paste the URL of the external website. In the Caption box, type the text of the link. Click anywhere in the Wiki text box to update the link, and then copy the link. Click OK to close the dialog box. Click the position in the text where you want the link to be, and then paste the link. In the formatting toolbar, click Save . If you opened the article in the Wiki Editor form, alternatively, you can click Save in the Wiki Editor form toolbar to save your changes and exit the editing mode. Check the link displayed in the article by clicking the link text. In Acumatica Wiki, you use the following basic format for a link: [ArticleID|LinkText] where ArticleID is the identifier of the article, and LinkText is the text of the link. The user clicks on this word or phrase to navigate to the article for which you specify the identifier. Here are some examples of wiki links: [Glossary] : This text is displayed as a link. [Glossary|This is a link to the Glossary] : This link is displayed with a custom link text ( This is a link to the Glossary This is a link to the Glossary); clicking the link opens the Glossary article. [~/Pages/GL/GL202500.aspx|Chart of Accounts] : This link redirects the user to a form in the General Ledger module of Acumatica ERP. By using external links, you can redirect users to external websites and mail-to links. Here are some examples of external links: [http://google.com] : The system displays this link as a string with the external link icon: . [mail@server.com] : The system displays this text as a mail-to link: . [mail@server.com|Contact us] : The system displays this string as a mail-to link with a custom link text: Contact us Contact us.

To Add a Graphic At times, you might want to illustrate the concepts or ideas in an article. To do this, you can import graphics to add them to articles. In the process, you can specify a variety of display options. To Import a Graphic File Before you import your file, make sure that the size of your file does not exceed the maximum file size allowed and that the type of file is allowed. You can check the maximum allowable file size and the valid file extensions on the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202550|SM202550]) File Upload Preferences (SM202550) form. To import a graphic file for an article, do the following: Open the article to which you want to add the graphic. Open the article for editing. Do one of the following: Click Edit to the right of the section to which you want to add the graphic. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the entire article in the Wiki Editor form. On the formatting toolbar, click Attach File . Alternatively, if you opened the Wiki Editor form, you can click Attach on the Wiki Editor form toolbar. This opens the File Upload dialog box. In the File Upload dialog box, click Browse to find the file, select the file, and then click Upload . This opens the File Link Editor dialog box. In the File Link Editor dialog box, specify the following options: File Link Editor Dialog Box In the Type box, select one of the following display options: Not Set , Thumb , Frame , or Border . In the Alignment box, select one of the following alignment options: Not Set , Right , Left , or Center . In the Caption box, enter the caption for the graphic. In the Size box, enter the display size (in pixels) of the graphic to be displayed. For more information, see the Customize a Graphic Customize a Graphic section of this article. Click anywhere in the Wiki text box to update the link, and then copy the link. Click OK to close the dialog box. Click on the position in the text where you want to insert the graphic, and paste the link. Click Save . Check the graphic displayed in the article, and correct the options if needed. To Update a Graphic File When you need to replace a graphic, do the following: Open the wiki article with the graphic you want to update. Click the Edit link next to the graphic you want to replace. The system redirects you to the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510]) File Maintenance (SM202510) form with the file name of the graphic specified in the File box. The form displays the list of versions of the file. Make sure the file name of the graphic begins with the correct article ID, separated from the graphic file name by a backslash (\). If the article ID has changed, delete the old link and create a new one. On the form toolbar, click Check Out . On the form toolbar, click Upload New Version . In the File Upload dialog box, click Browse and select the graphic you want to upload. Make sure the Check In check box is selected to check in the updated version of the file. Click Upload . The system uploads the file and adds it to the list of file versions under the original file name (regardless of the name of the uploaded file). By default, the new version of the file will be displayed in the article. To Customize a Graphic You may need to change how a graphic is justified in the text, scale it, or alter other display options. This section describes the wiki markup syntax you use to customize an graphic. See below for the most basic syntax for adding a graphic to a wiki article: [image: File name ] where File name has the following format: [ Article ID \ Image file name ] For example, the following syntax displays the graphic without borders and a caption: [image:Graphic\Links.png] The following graphic corresponds to the markup above: You use the following complete syntax to add a graphic to a wiki article: [Image:File name|Type|Location|Caption|Size|Noclick|] Follow these tips when you use these options, which the remainder of this article describes in detail: List the options in any order. Use no additional spaces before, between, or after any pipe sign (|) because spaces can cause errors when the system parses the link. Note that if the text between two pipe signs is not a valid option, the system interprets it as a caption. Options Available for Wiki Graphics Option Description Type Specifies the type of the graphic. Use one of the following values: thumb , frame , border, and popup . This is an example of the syntax for a thumbnail of a graphic: [image:Adding Pictures\Favorites.GIF|thumb|Favorites] The graphic is scaled down to 180 pixels and has a box around it, as shown in the screenshot below. The caption provided by the string ( Links ) is shown below the graphic and inside the box. Thumbnail of a Graphic If you click the graphic, the system opens a new blank page and displays the graphic at its actual size, as shown in the screenshot below. To return to the article, click the Back button of the browser. Graphic at Actual Size This is an example of the syntax for a graphic with a frame around it: [image:Graphic\Links.png|frame|Links] The system displays the graphic corresponding to the above syntax in its original size, with a box (frame) around it, as shown in the screenshot below. Notice the caption below the graphic and inside the box. Framed Graphic This is an example of the syntax for a graphic with a border: [image:Graphic\Links.png|Links|border] With the above syntax, the system displays the graphic in its original size with no caption, even if one is specified. The system adds a border around the graphic, as shown in the screenshot below. Graphic with Border This is an example of the syntax for a pop-up graphic: [image:Graphic\Links.png|popup|150px|Links] The graphic is displayed at the specified size (150 pixels). Thumbnail of a Pop-up Graphic When you click the graphic, the system opens the graphic in its original size in a pop-up dialog box with a dark gray background. To return to the article, press Esc. Pop-up Graphic Location Defines the horizontal placement of the graphic on the page. Use one of the following values: right , left , or center . By default, the system displays graphics left-aligned. This is an example of the syntax for a centered graphic: [image:Graphic\Links.png|Links|center] Centered Graphic Caption Specifies the tooltip shown when a user points to the graphic. This is an example of the syntax for a graphic with the caption option: [image:Graphic\Links.png|Links] The corresponding image is shown in the screenshot below. The Links text, interpreted as a caption, is shown when you point to the image. Graphic with Caption Size Gives you the ability to scale the graphic in either of the following ways: To the specified width, with the aspect ratio as in the original graphic: The syntax is N px, where N is a number of pixels. To both the specified width and height: The syntax is N x M px, where N specifies the number of pixels for the width and M specifies the number of pixels for the height. This is an example of the syntax for a graphic with the specified height and width: [image:Graphic\Links.png|100x50px|Links] The graphic is scaled down to 100 pixels in width and 50 pixels in height, as shown in the screenshot below. Scaled Graphic If you click the scaled graphic, the system opens the graphic in its actual size on a blank page. To return to the article, click the Back button of the browser. Graphic at Actual Size NoClick Prohibits the user from displaying the graphic in its actual size. See the following example of the syntax for a graphic with the noclick option: [image:Graphic\Links.png|100px|Links|noclick] The syntax above results in the graphic being scaled down proportionally to 100 pixels in width. When you click this graphic, the system does not open the graphic in its actual size. Graphic with Noclick Option To Attach Already Imported Files You can easily attach one file to different articles. To attach a file that is already imported into the system, do the following: Open the wiki article with the graphic you want to use. Open the article for editing. Do one of the following: Click Edit to the right of the section to where the graphic is located. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the entire article in the Wiki Editor form. Select and copy the image link. Click Cancel . Open the wiki article where you want to insert the graphic. Open the article for editing. Do one of the following: Click Edit to the right of the section to which you want to add the graphic. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the entire article in the Wiki Editor form. On the formatting toolbar, click Attach File . Alternatively, if you opened the Wiki Editor form, you can click Attach File on the Wiki Editor form toolbar. This opens the File Upload dialog box. In the File Upload dialog box, select Link to existing file option, paste the link into the Existing File dialog box, and then click Upload . This opens the File Link Editor dialog box. Follow Steps 5 through 10 of the Importing Graphic Files Importing Graphic Files procedure. ([~/?ScreenId=SM202550|SM202550]) ([~/?ScreenId=SM202510|SM202510])

You can easily build a table by using wiki markup. ==To Understand Table Markup== See below for descriptions of the basic wiki markup for tables, which you should use at the beginning of a line. [anchor|#table_cp1_5tk_mj] {| class="checklist" | width="100%" |- !width="21%" ! Markup Element !width="78%" ! Description |- | {| | The beginning of the table. Table parameters may be defined on the first line. |- | |+ | The table title (caption) line. |- | |} | The end of the table. |- | ! | A column heading. |- | !! | A column heading separator if headings are all specified on one line. |- | | | The beginning of a table cell. |- | || | A cell separator if all cells are specified on one line. |- | |- | A table row separator. |- | width=“x%“ | Column width, where ''x'' is the predefined width in %. Insert the attribute before the column name, with column heading separators on both sides. |} ==To Define a Simple Table== See below for an example of the wiki markup to define a simple table. This example shows all the column headings in one line, separated by {{!!}}, with the row headings ({{1.x}} and {{2.x}}) on separate lines. All cells for each row are listed in one line. {{{{{| ! X !! x.1 !! x.2 |- ! 1.x | Cell 1.1 || Cell 1.2 |- ! 2.x | Cell 2.1 || Cell 2.2 |} }}}} If you have long phrases in the cells or in the headings, you can define each cell in a separate line, as shown below. {{{{{| ! X ! x.1 ! x.2 |- ! 1.x | Cell 1.1 | Cell 1.2 |- ! 2.x | Cell 2.1 | Cell 2.2 |} }}}} Both of the syntax examples above generate the same table, as shown below.[anchor|#_c4j_zsz_wg][image:UserGuide/Images/Adding_Tables_sample1.png|popup|150px] You can use parameters, described in the following sections, to affect how the table looks. ==To Define Table Borders== You specify the parameters of the table borders, among other parameters, after the {| characters that designate the start of the table. See the following examples of the syntax to define table borders: *{{border="1"}}: Adds an overall border around the table and borders between the cells. *{{border="1" style="border: solid 5px #000000;"}}: Adds borders as the previous example does, but makes the outer border black and 5 pixels thick.
Use the syntax below to generate a table with a border around the outside and between cells.{{{{{| border="1" ! X !! x.1 !! x.2 |- ! 1.x | Cell 1.1 || Cell 1.2 |- ! 2.x | Cell 2.1 || Cell 2.2 |} }}}}[anchor|#_shm_qsz_wg][image:UserGuide/Images/Adding_Tables_sample2.png|popup|150px] Use the syntax below to generate the table with a thick red border.{{{{{| border="1" style="border: solid 5px Red;" ! X !! x.1 !! x.2 |- ! 1.x | Cell 1.1 || Cell 1.2 |- ! 2.x | Cell 2.1 || Cell 2.2 |} }}}}[anchor|#image_dmn_ck3_x3][image:UserGuide/Images/Adding_Tables_sample3.png|popup|150px] ==To Add Cell Spacing and Padding== To add space to the cells and between cells, use the ''cellspacing'' and ''cellpadding'' parameters, as shown in the following examples: *{{cellspacing="10"}}: The ''cellspacing'' parameter defines space between cells. (The default value is 1 pixel.) When ''cellspacing'' is set to “0“, as in this example, the borders of the neighboring cells merge into one line. *{{cellpadding="4"}}: The ''cellpadding'' parameter adds space to the cells, padding them in all directions. This example adds 4 pixels to cell space in each of 4 directions: above, below, right, and left.
Use the following syntax to generate the table (shown below the syntax) with enlarged spacing in the cells and between the cells.{{{{{| cellspacing="10" cellpadding="4" border="1" style="border: solid 1px #000000;" ! X !! x.1 !! x.2 |- ! 1.x | Cell 1.1 || Cell 1.2 |- ! 2.x | Cell 2.1 || Cell 2.2 |} }}}}[anchor|#_dft_msz_wg][image:UserGuide/Images/Adding_Tables_sample4.png|popup|150px] ==To Use Color== Use the syntax below to generate a table (shown below the syntax) with text color set to brown, background color set to yellow, and enlarged spacing in the cells.{{{{{| cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4" border="1" style="color:brown;background-color:yellow;" ! X !! x.1 !! x.2 |- ! 1.x | Cell 1.1 || Cell 1.2 |- ! 2.x | Cell 2.1 || Cell 2.2 |} }}}}[anchor|#_o3g_1sz_wg][image:UserGuide/Images/Adding_Tables_sample5.png|popup|150px] Use the syntax below to generate a table with a gray background color for the table heading (shown below the syntax).{{{{{| cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4" border="1" |- style="background-color: #D0D0D0;" ! X !! x.1 !! x.2 |- ! 1.x | Cell 1.1 || Cell 1.2 |- ! 2.x | Cell 2.1 || Cell 2.2 |} }}}}[anchor|#_fxx_prz_wg][image:UserGuide/Images/Adding_Tables_sample6.png|popup|150px] You can also add color to the row headings. The following syntax sets the background color of the table heading to black, the text color of the table heading to gray, and the background color of the row headings to a different shade of gray.{{{{{| cellspacing="0" cellpadding="4" border="1" style="border: solid 6px Blue;" |- style="background-color: #000000; color: #CCCCCC;" ! X !! x.1 !! x.2 |- | style="background-color: #D0D0D0;" | 1.x | Cell 1.1 || Cell 1.2 |- | style="background-color: #D0D0D0;" | 2.x | Cell 2.1 || Cell 2.2 |} }}}} The syntax above generates the table below. [anchor|#_o3s_vsz_wg][image:UserGuide/Images/Adding_Tables_sample7.png|popup|150px]

Dashboards can be configured for each module. If no components were added to the dashboard for a particular module, the default help article will be displayed.{br}
To add an article to a dashboard, do the following: [anchor|#_ef1_4pd_rg] #Open the article. #On the form title bar, click '''Dashboard''' and select '''Add Wiki'''. #In the '''Widget Properties''' dialog box, select the target dashboard. #Click '''OK'''.
row.PlainText: To Add an Article to a Dashboard Dashboards can be configured for each module. If no components were added to the dashboard for a particular module, the default help article will be displayed. To add an article to a dashboard, do the following: Open the article. On the form title bar, click Dashboard and select Add Wiki . In the Widget Properties dialog box, select the target dashboard. Click OK .

[anchor|#VtWT] You can add a new article in one of the following ways:[anchor|#_kyd_c25_xg] *By using the wiki toolbar button. *By using the '''Create a New Article''' link. [anchor|#_f2862694-ec3f-47f9-8538-61c998721d27] ==To Add an Article by Using the Wiki Toolbar Button== To create an article in any folder or to create a wiki folder, do the following:[anchor|#ol_cd2_pbt_kj] #Open any wiki article or folder. #On the wiki toolbar, click '''Add New Article''' to open the Wiki Editor form for a new article or folder. The '''Parent Folder''' and '''Category''' boxes have the same settings as those of the article or folder you opened; change these settings if necessary. #On the '''Content''' tab, in the '''Article ID''' and '''Name''' boxes, type the ID and name for the new article. You can use the same value in both boxes. #Optional: If you’re creating a folder, select the '''Folder''' check box. #In the text box, type the article text. For more information about wiki markup, see [HelpRoot_Administration\DM__con_Wiki_Using_Wiki_Markup|Wiki Markup Reference]. #:((({S:Hint}If you save the article without adding any text, the article will still be displayed in the wiki tree, but it will have no content. ))) #Optional: On the '''Properties''' tab, fill in the '''Summary''' and '''Keywords''' boxes. This step helps users find information when they perform quick searches (for which the system searches article properties and not full text). #On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click '''Save'''.
==To Add an Article by Using the Create a New Article Link== To create a new article by using the link in the navigation pane, do the following: #Open the wiki to which you want to add an article. #In the navigation pane, click '''Create a new article'''. #On the '''Contents''' tab, in the '''Parent Folder''' box, select the folder to hold the new article. #Optional: Select a category for the article based on your corporate requirements. #Follow Steps 3 through 7 in the [[#_f2862694-ec3f-47f9-8538-61c998721d27|To Add an Article by Using the Wiki Toolbar Button] section of this topic.

To Add an Article You can add a new article in one of the following ways: By using the wiki toolbar button. By using the Create a New Article link. To Add an Article by Using the Wiki Toolbar Button To create an article in any folder or to create a wiki folder, do the following: Open any wiki article or folder. On the wiki toolbar, click Add New Article to open the Wiki Editor form for a new article or folder. The Parent Folder and Category boxes have the same settings as those of the article or folder you opened; change these settings if necessary. On the Content tab, in the Article ID and Name boxes, type the ID and name for the new article. You can use the same value in both boxes. Optional: If you're creating a folder, select the Folder check box. In the text box, type the article text. For more information about wiki markup, see Wiki Markup Reference. If you save the article without adding any text, the article will still be displayed in the wiki tree, but it will have no content. Optional: On the Properties tab, fill in the Summary and Keywords boxes. This step helps users find information when they perform quick searches (for which the system searches article properties and not full text). On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save . To Add an Article by Using the Create a New Article Link To create a new article by using the link in the navigation pane, do the following: Open the wiki to which you want to add an article. In the navigation pane, click Create a new article . On the Contents tab, in the Parent Folder box, select the folder to hold the new article. Optional: Select a category for the article based on your corporate requirements. Follow Steps 3 through 7 in the To Add an Article by Using the Wiki Toolbar Button To Add an Article by Using the Wiki Toolbar Button section of this topic.

To Create a Folder When an article is also a folder, the article appears as a node in the wiki tree and may contain articles. To Define an Article as a Folder You can define a new or existing article as a folder. For more information about creating a new folder—that is, creating an article and defining it as a folder—see To Add an Article. To define an existing article as a folder, do the following: Open the article. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit to open the Wiki Editor form. On the Content tab, select the Folder check box. On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save . After you have defined an article as a folder, if you open the article in the Wiki Editor form, you can see the Subarticles tab. To Add Articles to a Folder You can populate a folder with articles by moving existing articles into the folder or by creating new articles in the folder. To move existing articles to the folder, use the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202010|SM202010]) Wiki Site Map (SM202010) form. If you're creating a new article, open the article in the Wiki Editor form, and on the Contents tab, specify the folder in the Parent Folder box. To Convert a Folder into an Article A folder can be converted to an article only if the folder doesn't contain any articles. For more information about moving the articles to another folder, see To Move an Article. To convert a folder into an article, do the following: Open the folder you want to convert. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the Wiki Editor form. On the Content tab, clear the Folder check box. On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save .

You can rename any article. An article is identified by its name and ID, and you can change either or both of these attributes. The system displays the article name in the wiki tree and at the top of the article. You use the article ID (and, optionally, the name) when you create links to the article. {br}
To rename an article, do the following: [anchor|#_omg_2sd_rg] #Open the article. #On the wiki toolbar, click '''Edit Current Article''' to open the Wiki Editor form. #Optional: On the '''Content''' tab, change the article name in the '''Name''' box. #Optional: Change the article identifier in the '''Article ID''' box. #On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click '''Save'''. If you have changed the name, the system displays the new name in the wiki tree. If you have changed the article ID, the system automatically updates all links to the article to reflect the new article ID.

The system displays the article name in the wiki tree and at the top of the article. You use the article ID (and, optionally, the name) when you create links to the article. To rename an article, do the following: Open the article. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the Wiki Editor form. Optional: On the Content tab, change the article name in the Name box. Optional: Change the article identifier in the Article ID box. On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save . If you have changed the name, the system displays the new name in the wiki tree. Be sure this is what you want to do before you delete the folder. ))) ==To Delete an Article== To delete an article, do the following:[anchor|#_c31_ksd_rg] #Open the article. #On the wiki toolbar, click '''Delete Article'''. #In the '''Delete Article''' dialog box, click '''Yes''' to confirm that you want to delete the article.
The deleted article is moved to the '''Deleted Items''' folder. This gives you an opportunity to recover accidentally deleted articles and restore them. To Delete an Article You can delete an article along with all its versions as long as you have sufficient access rights to do so. If you delete a folder, you will delete all of its contents, including all its articles and subfolders. Be sure this is what you want to do before you delete the folder. To Delete an Article To delete an article, do the following: Open the article. On the wiki toolbar, click Delete Article . In the Delete Article dialog box, click Yes to confirm that you want to delete the article. The deleted article is moved to the Deleted Items folder. This gives you an opportunity to recover accidentally deleted articles and restore them. For more information, see To Restore a Deleted Article. To Permanently Delete an Article If you want to permanently delete an article from the wiki, do the following: In the navigation pane, open the Deleted Items folder. Open the article you want to permanently delete. On the wiki toolbar, click Delete Article . In the Delete Article dialog box, click Yes to confirm the deletion.

row.Content: Once authorized users have deleted an article, the system places it in the '''Deleted Items''' folder in the navigation pane. Deleted articles remain in this folder until they are permanently deleted. To restore an article from the '''Deleted Items''' folder, do the following:[anchor|#_a4n_4sd_rg] #Open the '''Deleted Items''' folder. #Open the article you want to restore. #On the wiki toolbar, click '''Edit Current Article''' to open the Wiki Editor form. #In the '''Parent Folder''' box, select the folder to hold the restored article. #On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click '''Save'''.
row.PlainText: To Restore a Deleted Article Once authorized users have deleted an article, the system places it in the Deleted Items folder in the navigation pane. Deleted articles remain in this folder until they are permanently deleted. To restore an article from the Deleted Items folder, do the following: Open the Deleted Items folder. Open the article you want to restore. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the Wiki Editor form. In the Parent Folder box, select the folder to hold the restored article. On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save .

If you move an article that is a folder, it is moved along with its contents. ==To Move an Article Across Folders== To move an article between folders: #Open the article. #On the wiki toolbar, click '''Edit Current Article''' to open the Wiki Editor form. #On the '''Contents''' tab, in the '''Parent Folder''' box, select the folder where you want to place the article. #On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click '''Save'''.

To view the new order of articles in the folder, reload or refresh the page. ((({S:Hint}You can also change the order of articles in a folder by using the [HelpRoot_FormReference\SM_20_20_10|Wiki Site Map] ([~/?ScreenId=SM202010|SM202010]) form. )))

To Move an Article You can move an article to a different folder or to a different position within the current folder. If you move an article that is a folder, it is moved along with its contents. To Move an Article Across Folders To move an article between folders: Open the article. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the Wiki Editor form. On the Contents tab, in the Parent Folder box, select the folder where you want to place the article. On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save . To Move Articles Within a Folder To rearrange articles within a folder, do the following: Open the folder that holds the article. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the Wiki Editor form. On the Subarticles tab, select the article you want to move. To change the position of the article within the folder, do one of the following: On the table toolbar, click Move Up to move the article one row up in the list On the table toolbar, click Move Down to move the article one row down. Repeat Step 4 until you've moved the article where it should be. Repeat Steps 3 to 5 for each article you want to move. On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save . To view the new order of articles in the folder, reload or refresh the page. You can also change the order of articles in a folder by using the ([~/?ScreenId=SM202010|SM202010]) Wiki Site Map (SM202010) form.

In Acumatica ERP, you configure access rights for roles rather than for individual users, and you assign users to roles. By default, access rights for an article or folder are inherited from the parent folder, but you can change access rights to an article or folder, as described below. ((({S:Hint}Only users with the ''Delete'' level of access to the article can manage access to the article. ))) To quickly change access rights for a particular article or folder, do the following: [anchor|#_fkz_btd_rg] #Open the article. #On the wiki toolbar, click '''Edit Current Article''' to open the Wiki Editor form. #On the '''Access Rights''' tab, modify the access rights of each role to the article or leave them as they are inherited from the parent folder. For each role, select one of the following options, listed from the most restrictive to the broadest access rights: #*''Inherited'': Defines the access to the article by the type of access specified for the parent folder. #*''Revoked'': Denies users with the role any access to the article. #*''View Only'': Allows users with the role to view the article text but not to make changes. #*''Edit'': Allows users with the role to make changes to the article text. #*''Insert'': Gives users the ''View'' and ''Edit'' rights, as well as the ability to create new articles in the same parent folder. #*''Publish'': Allows users with the role to publish the article and any subarticles within it, in addition to granting the ''Insert'' rights. #*''Delete'': Allows users with the role to delete the article and its subarticles, in addition to granting the ''Publish'' rights. #On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click '''Save'''.

To Update Access Rights to an Article In Acumatica ERP, you configure access rights for roles rather than for individual users, and you assign users to roles. By default, access rights for an article or folder are inherited from the parent folder, but you can change access rights to an article or folder, as described below. Only users with the Delete level of access to the article can manage access to the article. To quickly change access rights for a particular article or folder, do the following: Open the article. On the wiki toolbar, click Edit Current Article to open the Wiki Editor form. On the Access Rights tab, modify the access rights of each role to the article or leave them as they are inherited from the parent folder. For each role, select one of the following options, listed from the most restrictive to the broadest access rights: Inherited : Defines the access to the article by the type of access specified for the parent folder. Revoked : Denies users with the role any access to the article. View Only : Allows users with the role to view the article text but not to make changes. Edit : Allows users with the role to make changes to the article text. Insert : Gives users the View and Edit rights, as well as the ability to create new articles in the same parent folder. Publish : Allows users with the role to publish the article and any subarticles within it, in addition to granting the Insert rights. Delete : Allows users with the role to delete the article and its subarticles, in addition to granting the Publish rights. On the Wiki Editor form toolbar, click Save .
